Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The anticodon sequence GGA of the serine tRNA gene is mutated to CUA

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The anticodon sequence GUA of the tyrosine tRNA gene is mutated to CUA

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The anticodon sequence GUA of the tyrosine tRNA gene is mutated to UUA

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: UCU is mutated to UCA in the anticodon. This mutation is believed to confer UGA suppressor activity on the arginine tRNA.

Readthrough mechanism: no mention
reassignment
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: Variant genetic codes reassign standard stop codons to amino acids

Readthrough mechanism: reassignment
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: Variant genetic codes reassign standard stop codons to amino acids

Readthrough mechanism: a base mutation outside the anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: A base mutation at position 24 from G to A in the stem of the dihydrouracil loop

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The amber suppressor gene is the structural gene for one of the tyrosine tRNAs of E. coli. The mutation results in a base change in the anticodon of this tRNA from GUA to CUA.This change enables the tRNA to recognize the amber codon UAG instead of the tyrosine codons UAU and UAC.

Readthrough mechanism: oligonucleotide-directed site-specific mutagenesis
Mutational position of sup-tRNA:
Amber and ochre suppressor tRNA genes have been generated by using oligonucleotide directed site-specific mutagenesis to change one or two nucleotides in a human serine
tRNA gene.

Readthrough mechanism: oligonucleotide-directed site-specific mutagenesis
Mutational position of sup-tRNA:
Amber and ochre suppressor tRNA genes have been generated by using oligonucleotide directed site-specific mutagenesis to change one or two nucleotides in a human serine
tRNA gene.

Readthrough mechanism: frameshift suppressor,insertion of a base in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: SUF2:The insertion of a G-C base pair at a position in the gene that corresponds to the anticodon loop of the proline tRNA results in the replacement of the wild-type anticodon AGG by a AGGG four-base anticodon which enables the tRNA to suppress the CCCU four-base codons generated as the result of the his4-712 and his4-713 frameshift mutations.

Readthrough mechanism: frameshift suppressor,a base mutation outside the anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA:
Suppressor mutations in the SUF7 and SUF8 genes result in G-to-U base substitutions at position 39 that disrupted the normal G·C base pairing in the last base pair of the anticodon stem adjacent to the anticodon loop. 
These anticodon stem mutations might alter the size of the anticodon loop and permit the use of a UGGG sequence within the loop to read 4-base proline codons.

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: sup5:a mutant of tyrosine tRNA which has the anticodon CΨA instead of the normal GΨA.

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: SUP-RL1:the suppressor serine tRNA can read the codon UAG through a G to U anticodon base change

Readthrough mechanism: wobble
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The tRNA Gln has the anticodon CUG allowing glutamine insertion and an inefficient translational readthrough of UAG by wobble in the first position of the codon.

Readthrough mechanism: frameshift suppressor,insertion of a base in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: sufD:the frameshift suppressor mutation produce a glycine tRNA with the nucleotide quadruplet CCCC at the anticodon position, instead of the triplet CCC found in wildtype.

Readthrough mechanism: frameshift suppressor,insertion of a base in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: sufD:the frameshift suppressor mutation produce a glycine tRNA with the nucleotide quadruplet CCCC at the anticodon position, instead of the triplet CCC found in wildtype.

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: sup8:a nucleotide change in the anticodon which allows for complementary base pair recognition of the UGA codon

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: sup3:a base substitution in the second anticodon position

Readthrough mechanism: reassignment
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: A shortening of the tRNATrp anticodon stem from fve to four base pairs

Readthrough mechanism: wobble
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The mitochondrial tRNA Trp anticodon is UCA. Because there is a U in the wobble position, this tRNA  can recognize and insert tryptophan into a growing polypeptide chain in response to the nonsense codon UGA

Readthrough mechanism: other
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The wild-type and psu1+ tRNAs have the same sequence except for their anticodons, where NGA in the wild-type species is mutated to CUA in the psu1+ species.These mutations confer suppressor activity on the tRNA by enabling it to recognize the UAG nonsense codon.

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The wild-type and psu2+ tRNAs have the same sequence except for their anticodons, where NUG in the wild-type species is mutated to NUA in the psu2+ species (N is a modified residue of U). The anticodon change confers suppressor activity on the glutamine tRNA by enabling it to recognize amber (UAG) and ochre (UAA) codons.(The modified nucleotide N recognizes both G and A in the third position of the codon.)

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon,other
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The wild-type glutamlne tRNA has the antlcodon NUG, and the psu2+ single-mutant tRNA has the anticodon NUA, a pu2+-C34 double mutant has CUA,which can suppress UAG.

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: supD:A single nudeotide mutation in the middle of the anticodon from G to A allows the suppressor tRNA to read the UAG stop codon.

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: supP:The leuX151 mutation effects a substitution (from U to A) of the middle base in the leuX tRNA Leu anticodon to generate CUA, which can recognize the UAG amber codon.

Readthrough mechanism: a single base mutation in anticodon
Mutational position of sup-tRNA: The suppressor tRNA derived from tRNA Trp, which inserts glutamine in response to UAG, has a C for U substitution in the middle base of the anticodon. The mutational change alters both the coding specificity and amino acid-acceptor specificity(a loss of tryptophan-accepting specificity and the acquisition of glutamine-acceptor activity).
